foreignersBuy.title: Can foreigners buy real estate in the Czech Republic?
foreignersBuy.content:
Yes, but with some restrictions:
- EU citizens can buy property freely.
- Non-EU citizens can buy residential property if they have a long-term residence permit or establish a Czech company to hold the property.
- Agricultural and forest land has stricter regulations for non-EU buyers.

popularCities.title: What are the most popular cities for real estate investment?
popularCities.content:
- Prague (highest demand, strong rental market)
- Brno (growing tech hub, student rentals)
- Ostrava (lower prices, industrial redevelopment)
- Karlovy Vary & Český Krumlov (tourist hotspots, short-term rentals)

marketPerformance.title: How is the Czech real estate market performing?
marketPerformance.content:
- Prague remains stable with steady price growth.
- Regional cities offer better affordability and rental yields.
- Interest rates have risen, slightly cooling demand.

buyingSteps.title: What are the steps to buying property in the Czech Republic?
buyingSteps.content:
1. Find a property (via real estate agents or online portals like Sreality.cz, Bezrealitky.cz).
2. Sign a reservation agreement (usually requires a deposit).
3. Conduct due diligence (check land registry, debts, zoning).
4. Sign a purchase contract (notarization required).
5. Register ownership in the Cadastral Register (Katastr nemovitostí).

feesAndTaxes.title: What fees and taxes apply when buying property?
feesAndTaxes.content:
- Property transfer tax (4%) – Paid by the buyer (some exemptions apply).
- Real estate agent fee (typically 2–6%, paid by seller or buyer depending on agreement).
- Notary & legal fees (approx. 0.5–1% of property value).
- Land registry fee (around CZK 1,000–5,000).

needLawyer.title: Do I need a lawyer when buying property?
needLawyer.content:
Highly recommended to:
- Check legal title & encumbrances.
- Review contracts.
- Ensure proper registration.

foreignersMortgage.title: Can foreigners get a mortgage in the Czech Republic?
foreignersMortgage.content:
Yes, but conditions vary:
- EU citizens can get mortgages more easily.
- Non-EU citizens may need a higher down payment (30–50%) and proof of income.
- Interest rates currently range from 4–6%.

sellingTaxes.title: What taxes apply when selling property?
sellingTaxes.content:
- Capital gains tax (15%) – Applies if sold within 5 years of purchase (exempt if it was your primary residence).
- No inheritance or gift tax (but income tax may apply).

sellingTime.title: How long does it take to sell a property?
sellingTime.content:
- Prague: 2–6 months (depending on price & location).
- Smaller towns: May take longer.

rentingInvestment.title: Is renting property a good investment in the Czech Republic?
rentingInvestment.content:
- Prague offers 4–6% rental yields.
- Student cities (Brno, Olomouc) have high demand.
- Short-term rentals (Airbnb) are profitable in tourist areas but face increasing regulation.

tenantRights.title: What are tenant rights in the Czech Republic?
tenantRights.content:
- Standard lease duration: 1+ year.
- Landlord can increase rent once per year (with notice).
- Eviction requires a court order (except for serious violations).

cadastralRegister.title: What is the Cadastral Register (Katastr nemovitostí)?
cadastralRegister.content: The official land registry where property ownership, mortgages, and restrictions are recorded. Always verify details before buying.

residencePermit.title: Do I need a residence permit to buy property?
residencePermit.content: No, but non-EU buyers may need a company or residency to purchase residential property.

shortTermRentals.title: Are there restrictions on short-term rentals (Airbnb)?
shortTermRentals.content:
- Prague requires registration and limits short-term rentals in some areas.
- Other cities may introduce similar rules.
